comments.commentBody:
Except for presumably all those good suburbanites, many of whom are "Democrats", who overwhelmingly opposed tax increases a few months ago for Metro transit.

Now, the mostly working poor will face a 17% cut in service this fall.

Because suburbanites, with their belching cars, could not be troubled to help the contemptible poor and their miserable transit needs.
Wow.

Thank you, John Smith, for making the plaintiffs' case in the upcoming court battle. It's not students voting in college towns that you oppose, it's ANYBODY who is only 18, because you figure they will foolishly vote for liberal candidates.

That may be, and not just for economic reasons. Students, for example: a party a majority of whose members claim not to believe in evolution is not likely to get a lot of traction on a college or university campus, where courses from astronomy to zoology kind of assume an understanding of the history of the earth and universe that is not found in the book of Genesis. Young people will not be impressed with candidates for president who speak dismissively of evolution.

Also, students and young people in general tend to be much more tolerant that their elders. They have close friends across this country's historic color lines, and may marry across them. They may be openly gay or have close friends who are, even in college fraternities, something that would have been unthinkable in their parents' time on campus.

As to economic issues: most students do work, all but trust fund types (many of whom probably vote Republican). They are aware of the unfair minimum wage, which is probably what they are paid for campus jobs in the library or dining hall, or similar work off-campus.

And yes, they pay taxes, including payroll taxes, as well as sales taxes and so forth.

I wonder how many college students regret their votes for Democrats once they actually have a job and start paying taxes? It's sad that someone who is 18 and has no concept of how much tax is taken out of one's paycheck by the Federal and State governments can cancel out the vote of a hard-working taxpayer.
Until 18 year olds can think for themselves and not regurgitate the liberal dogma taught by their high school teachers and college professors democracy will always be wasted on the young. C'est La Vie!
They can only take the cases that come their way.  It's not like SCOTUS is walking around talking about how it has a pen and a phone.

Staff, I'll grant you; they're usually drawn from the local population and likely to stay around. But, faculty? Should the registrar require proof of tenure before granting registration? What about the -- more and more common these days -- part-time faculty, not on tenure track, who spend one semester in one place, and move elsewhere for the next? Are they allowed to vote? If so, why not students, who spend the bets part of 4-5 years at their college?
What does anything you say have to do with being a "liberal"?

Perhaps the good professor would share with us the number of courses in economic history and the history of economic thought are required of econ majors and grad students.

As I read the undergraduate requirements, the number of required such courses appears to be zero, and the offerings only include two courses that might be considered history. It appears to be the same thing for PhDs, no requirement, and maybe one course.

Is it any wonder economists who run their mouths in public have so little "historical knowledge"?
Economic drought is not over,  considering the fundamentally flawed economic system, the worst is yet to come and went it hits, which is going to sooner then later all hell will break loose.

What a hodgepodge of a column, Maureen.

What I get from it is that some (particularly the young, technologically entitled) feel optimistic. Others are subdued or downright pessimistic. Others want a simplistic black versus white clarity with a possible return to a triumphant nationalism (might I add, this is the same type of thinking that brought Hitler to power in Germany.)

All told, this is pluralism in a nation slowly emerging from a long economic drought. Not especially ground-breaking news, even if it has disturbing elements.

Next time, I'll hope for a more insightful column.

Costa Rica "played amazingly well"?

What game were you watching?

No offense, no attempt to control the ball, no speed - and you call that "amazing" play?

The only "amazing" I saw from Costa Rica was an "amazing" display of poor sportsmanship, no effort to actually play a competitive match and another attempt to steal another match via the travesty known as the shoot-out.
Bullying behavior?  I trust you're not serious.

@Romero,  I agree with you, specially on the Jibe - yapping of the goalie, the ref should have warned him to stop it.  Having said that, that stuff goes on a lot and players should be able to either give it right back or ignore it.  If a player let's him/herself be intimidated like that, he/she won't succeed.
Mexican, I presume :)

Krull should've been shown a yellow card for his bullying behavior; so not an example for kids starting to play soccer... But the reality is: kids will learn to bully as Krull and to dive like Mr. BalleRobben, because they see that cheats and bullies get to advance to semifinals

It may have been "bush league," but it was well deserved "slight" considering the deliberate lack of effort that Costa Rica put into their game, much like what we saw in their previous game against Greece.

Costa Rica, "well organized," "filled with energy"?

Really?

Sorry, two minutes of "effort" at the end of the match does not make up for a travesty of a game plan that comprised of over 120 minutes of playing for a penalty shootout.

It was a disgraceful game plan, much like what we saw against Greece, and unworthy of a quarter-final match.
Last I checked, the point of the game is to win.

Yes, it would be exciting to see the refs and other game officials huddling around the score table adding up the game stats to determine a winner!  You're right that PKs aren't the perfect solution but, at least, skill and strategy still have a role in the outcome.

There are a couple of problems with using stats.  1) You're really, REALLY taking the decision off the playing field.  It would be like watching a split decision in boxing, which always disappoints fans.  2) You're arbitrarily deciding a winner since the stats are, themselves, arbitrary.  Which do you pick?  Which do you emphasize?  Does a team with one or two very clear chances deserve to lose to a team with a dozen easily-saved shots?  3) It would encourage teams to pad the relevant stats by taking silly shots, like shooting on goal every time you get within 30 yards.

No team as ever won the WC without an excellent defense. Defense comes in many shades. Many of you might have noticed that Holland did not always attack when they had control of the ball. They had the Ticos chasing the ball hoping to gain a benefit by exhausting them; Very similar to what Ali used to do(rope a dope) in boxing and Brazil's best kept secret weapon. I think changing the keeper was more of a psychological play; making the Ticos think he had some special talent stopping penalties; Krull demonstrated no such talent while playing for Newcastle. It also disguised the fact that all four penalties taken by Holland where short and quick, giving the CR keeper no time to read or react; that is where the game was won.

In the end, it would have been unjust if Holland had lost after dominating the game. Still, I would prefer other ways than PKs to decide a winner. How about using game stats instead, like shots on goal, saves, corners, etc.  This would motivate offensive play, which also makes the game more exciting to watch.   Even fouls and cards could be included in the mix.
This from a country which allows it's version of football to swap its entire team between offence and defence? Don't make me laugh.
Well - gotta play better, then. Well done the marvellous Ditch.
Gutsy move by van Gaal - if it hadn't worked the Euro press would have crucified him...
'Entitled'? Costa Rica played a strong defence but looked amateurish in attack, well done to them for the best they could have hoped for.
Like a relief pitcher?
Low scoring soccer games, like low scoring baseball games, are what the true fan lives for.

The German goalie in 1990 explained the rationale behind not guessing. If the kicker hits the ball correctly even a correct guess will not result in a save/block; hence, react. In this case if the ball is struck poorly one can stop it.  In watching penalty kicks this W.C. I believe I saw several cases of a wrong guess by the goalie leading to a score even though the ball was low enough and near enough to the center that a reaction seemed to have been a better choice. The only time a wrong guess does not result in a goal, is when the kicker totally misses (typically over the bar), as has happened.

As a former goalkeeper, I can tell you it is very difficult to make a save when you wait until the ball has been struck to pick a side of the goal to defend.  You don't have that kind of time if the ball is well-struck.  Krul saved two balls that were not well-placed and which had not been hit with power.  Contrast those with the perfect placements of the Dutch.  When you hit the side net on a penalty kick, it is essentially unstoppable regardless of the quality of the keeper.  In addition, I'm sure that Krul received plenty of coaching (and probably had watched tape) about the tendencies of the shooters to place the ball.  These are highly scouted players, especially in the Cup.

Actually Krul moved in the correct direction, i.e. that in which the shot was taken, on each of the kicks he faced.  Presumably he reacted only after the ball was, or was about to be, struck so that the direction was unmistakable.  This strategy is in distinct contrast to that followed by most goalkeepers when defending penalty kicks but can, I believe, shown probabliistically to be the approach most likely to produce a defended shot under a few mild assumptions about shooter accuracy and goalie coverage.  It is, I think, quite simialr to the Marilyn Vos Savant "goats and car" problem.
Would you call Koji Uehara, Dennis Eckersley or Mariano Rivera walk-ons?
Bravo, Liam!  Superb comment.

Lying is a crime only under special and restrictive circumstances (legal oath, fraud, etc.).  If you make it a crime, you criminalize free speech, because what is a lie is often a subjective judgment.

Amy -- I'd definitely include Faux News.  No news outlet -- bar none -- has been more corrupt in its deliberately slanted news "reporting" since Soviet era Pravda.  If you are suggesting that the NY Times is in the same class of bias, you are very wrong, indeed.

Jonathan - Politicians take a legal oath.  I cannot recite the oaths taken by Senators or Representatives, but I dare say that both contain terms infringed on by something as accepted (unfortunately) nowadays as deliberate denial of unambiguous scientific facts -- not beliefs or theories, but facts.  And before anyone reflexively comes back with comments about the Presidential oath, I'd offer caution on doing so because the most costly untruths from that branch of government -- truly historic untruths -- led to our needless war in Iraq, the severity and lasting ramifications of which simply have no peer since Watergate.

"But we also need to reduce the incentives for elites to spread misinformation to their followers in the first place."

Might I suggest prison for elected politicians who willfully, knowingly, or deliberately misinform the public for ulterior motives? A charlatan on a corner soapbox is one thing. An elected official empowered to craft laws but who lies to citizens in order to do so is surely committing a crime.

You took that quotation out of context. It clearly refers to the idea of voicing your opinion to your children about a particular instance that will have little or no effect on other people. The examples you cite are not even close to having the same context - they involve other people being hurt as a result.
mikenh, you're really good at ad hominem attacks! My hat's off to you. That's two in the comments for one column. So far, that is.
Regarding "The English Patient", I'm more inclined to agree with Elaine Benes's coment "So just DIE already!"
